_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Argo Chemical Inc. engages in the business of providing chemicals to end-users.  Its warehouse and storage facility located at 100 Quantico Ave. in Bakersfield, California, store various chemicals for resale.  The chemicals are purchased from manufacturers or their representatives, brought to the Argo Chemical facility, unloaded, stored, blended and reloaded for shipment to the customer.  The following are key elements of the RMP plan:

(a)    Argo Chemical is a retail operation subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard.  Argo incorporates all the elements of the Program 3 Prevention program, worstA?case scenario analysis, alternative release analysis, 5-year history, document management system, process safety information, training, mechanical integrity, incident investigation, compliance audit, management of change, pre-startup review, employee participation, hot work permits and emergency response plan.

(b)    The stationary sources and the regulated substances handled are:

Compressed Chlorine Gas
Argo Chemical handles this product in 150 pounds pressurized cylinders.  The cylinders are received via truck and unloaded using a forklift.  The full cylinders are stored by securing them to storage cradles made of steel.  For delivery to clients, the cylinders are loaded using a forklift onto the bed of a truck on which they are secured with straps during transport. 

Compressed Ammonia
Argo Chemical handles this product in 150 pounds pressurized cylinders and in 1000-gallon pressurized tanks.  The cylinders are received via truck and unloaded using a forklift.  The full cylinders are stored by securing them with chains to storage cradles made of steel.  For delivery to clients, the cylinders are loaded using a forklift onto the bed of a truck on which they are secured with straps during transport. Bulk shipments of anhydrous ammonia are received by pressurized transport and unloaded directly into the ammonia storage tank battery. Anhydrous

ammonia is used on site to produce aqua ammonia, and for delivery in smaller quantity.


Aqua Ammonia
This product, handled in bulk, is stored in 11,000 (19%) and 25,000 (29.5%) gallon tanks. It is loaded into shipping containers using pumps and, hoses with vapor return to the vessel from which the product is being removed.  

(c)    In the highly unlikely event (worst-case scenario) of a mechanical failure of one of the cylinders containing a compressed gas, a release of the contents of the cylinder may occur and have offsite consequences.  An alternative scenario involves a release of the compressed gas through a 1/8-inch in diameter hole in the cylinder wall caused by corrosion.  Minimum offsite consequences may result from such an alternative release scenario. 
In the case of aqua ammonia, the worst-case scenario is a release of the entire contents of the tank in 10 minutes. An alternative scenario is the release of 500 gallons in 10 minutes. In the case of anhydrous ammonia, the worst-case scenario is the release of the entire contents of one 1000-gallon storage tank in 10 minutes; an alternate scenario is the release of 35 gallons per minute of anhydrous ammonia for a period lasting 10 minutes.
The entire anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia handling facility has a water deluge system capable of delivering 100 gallons per minute of water in a form of a spray covering the plant in its entirety.

(d)    Argo Chemical has in place an accidental release prevention program, which, among others, includes Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Instructions, Compliance Audits and Training. 

(e)    Argo Chemical has an Emergency Response Plan and coordinates its activities with all applicable Governmental Agencies. 

(f)    Argo Chemical is committed to safe and responsible distribution of chemical products.  Operating Procedures     review and enhanced training of personnel in the safe handling of all chemical products is a continuing practice of Argo Chemi

cal, Inc. Forklift operations and truck-loading training is an ongoing process.  As technology and operation changes occur, additional training and improvement in loading equipment is  implemented.

Executive Summary

Argo Chemical Inc. engages in the business of providing chemicals to end-users.  Its warehouse and storage facility located at 100 Quantico Ave. in Bakersfield, California, store various chemicals for resale.  The chemicals are purchased from manufacturers or their representatives, brought to the Argo Chemical facility, unloaded, stored, blended and reloaded for shipment to the customer. (b)    The stationary sources and the regulated substances handled are:

Compressed Chlorine Gas
Argo Chemical handles this product in one ton and in 150 pounds pressurized cylinders.  The cylinders are received via truck and unloaded using a forklift.  The full cylinders are stored by securing them with chains to storage cradles made of steel. Compressed Ammonia
Argo Chemical handles this product in 150 pounds pressurized cylinders and in 8 1000-gallon pressurized tanks.  The cylinders are received via truck and unloaded using a forklift.  The full cylinders are stored by securing them with chains to storage cradles made of steel.  For delivery to clients, the cylinders are loaded u

sing a forklift onto the bed of a truck on which they are secured with straps during transport. Bulk shipments of anhydrous ammonia are received by pressurized transport and unloaded directly into the aqua ammonia storage tank battery. Anhydrous ammonia is used on site to produce aqua ammonia.


Aqua Ammonia
This product, handled in bulk, is stored in a 25,000(29.5%) and 11,000(19.5%)-gallon tanks. It is loaded into shipping containers using pumps and, hoses with vapor return to the vessel from which the product is being removed.  

(c)    In the highly unlikely event (worst-case scenario) of a mechanical failure of one of the cylinders containing a compressed gas, a release of the contents of the cylinder may occur and have offsite consequences. In the case of aqua ammonia, the worst-case scenario is a release of the entire contents of the tank in 10 minutes. An alternative scenario is the release of 500 gallons in 10 minutes. In the case of anhydrous ammonia, the worst-case scenario is the release of the entire contents of one 1000-gallon storage tank; an alternate scenario is the release of 35 gallons per minute of anhydrous ammonia for a period lasting 10 minutes.
The entire anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia handling facility has a water deluge system capable of delivering 100 gallons per minute of water in a form of a spray covering the plant in its entirety.

(d)    Argo Chemical has in place an accidental release prevention program, which, among others, includes Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Instructions, Compliance Audits and Training. 

(e)    Argo Chemical has an Emergency Response Plan and coordinates its activities with all applicable Governmental Agencies. 

(f)    Argo Chemical is committed to safe and res

ponsible distribution of chemical products.  Operating Procedures     review and enhanced training of personnel in the safe handling of all chemical products is a continuing goal of Argo Chemical, Inc. Forklift operations and truck-loading training is an ongoing process.  As technology and operation changes occur, additional training and improvement in loading equipment will be implemented.






3-31-04
